sites.name: Trinity College and The Book of Kells
sites.description: Trinity College is Dublin's oldest university, founded in 1592. It houses the Book of Kells, an illuminated manuscript Gospel book in Latin, famous for its intricate artwork.
sites.seasonal_notes: Busy during summer months; quieter during academic term.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended, especially during peak tourist seasons.

sites.name: Guinness Storehouse
sites.description: The Guinness Storehouse is a seven-story visitor experience located at St. James's Gate Brewery, showcasing the history and process of brewing Ireland's iconic beer.
sites.seasonal_notes: Can be crowded, especially during weekends and holidays.
sites.booking_tips: Online booking is recommended to secure a specific timeslot.

sites.name: Dublin Castle
sites.description: Dublin Castle has been at the heart of the history and evolution of the city. Originally built in the 13th century, it now serves as a major government complex and tourist attraction.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with special events and exhibitions.
sites.booking_tips: Guided tours are available and recommended for a comprehensive experience.

sites.name: St. Patrick's Cathedral
sites.description: St. Patrick's Cathedral is the largest church in Ireland, founded in 1191. It is known for its stunning Gothic architecture and its association with Jonathan Swift.
sites.seasonal_notes: Choir performances occur regularly, providing a unique experience.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets are available at the door; arrive early to avoid queues.

sites.name: Phoenix Park
sites.description: Phoenix Park is one of the largest enclosed public parks in any capital city in Europe. It is home to Dublin Zoo and the residence of the President of Ireland.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round, especially in spring and summer.
sites.booking_tips: Park entry is free, but some attractions within may require tickets.

sites.name: Temple Bar District
sites.description: Temple Bar is Dublin's cultural quarter, known for its vibrant nightlife, artistic venues, galleries, and the famous Temple Bar Pub.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lively all year, particularly busy during weekends.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required to explore the district, but pubs and restaurants can be crowded.

sites.name: Kilmainham Gaol
sites.description: Kilmainham Gaol played a key role in Irish history as many leaders of Irish rebellions were imprisoned and executed here. It now serves as a museum.
sites.seasonal_notes: Limited capacity; early booking recommended.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets should be purchased in advance, especially in peak seasons.

sites.name: National Gallery of Ireland
sites.description: The National Gallery of Ireland houses a rich collection of European and Irish art, including works by Caravaggio, Vel√°zquez, and Jack B. Yeats.
sites.seasonal_notes: Special exhibitions may draw larger crowds; quieter mid-week.
sites.booking_tips: Entry is free; special exhibitions might require tickets.

sites.name: Christ Church Cathedral
sites.description: Christ Church Cathedral is one of Dublin's oldest buildings, known for its stunning medieval architecture and crypt, which is the largest in Ireland.
sites.seasonal_notes: Special events and concerts often held here.
sites.booking_tips: Advance tickets recommended for concerts; general entry available on-site.

sites.name: Grafton Street
sites.description: Grafton Street is Dublin's premier shopping street, known for its high-end stores, street performers, and historic charm.
sites.seasonal_notes: Busy during weekends and holidays; street performances add vibrancy.
sites.booking_tips: No booking needed; explore at leisure.

sites.name: Merrion Square
sites.description: Merrion Square is a historic Georgian square noted for its well-preserved architecture, public park, and statue of Oscar Wilde.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful in spring and summer; hosts outdoor events.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required; open access to the park.

sites.name: Jameson Distillery Bow St.
sites.description: The Jameson Distillery offers an interactive tour exploring the history and making of Jameson Irish Whiskey.
sites.seasonal_notes: Tours run year-round; busier during tourist season.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended to ensure availability.

sites.name: Dublin Zoo
sites.description: Located in Phoenix Park, Dublin Zoo is one of the world's oldest zoos, featuring a wide variety of animal species and educational exhibits.
sites.seasonal_notes: Popular with families, especially during school holidays.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets can be bought online for convenience.

sites.name: National Museum of Ireland - Archaeology
sites.description: This museum houses an extensive collection of Irish artifacts from prehistoric to medieval times, including the famous Ardagh Chalice and the Tara Brooch.
sites.seasonal_notes: Free entry makes it popular year-round.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required; arrive early to avoid crowds.

sites.name: Dublin Writers Museum
sites.description: Dedicated to the literary heritage of Dublin, this museum showcases the works and lives of famous Irish writers such as James Joyce, Samuel Beckett, and W.B. Yeats.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open all year with special literary events.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets can be purchased at the entrance.

sites.name: The Spire of Dublin
sites.description: The Spire, also known as the Monument of Light, is a large, stainless steel, pin-like monument located on O'Connell Street. It stands at 120 meters tall.
sites.seasonal_notes: Illuminated at night, offering a striking view.
sites.booking_tips: Freely accessible; no tickets required.

sites.name: Ha'penny Bridge
sites.description: Officially known as the Liffey Bridge, this iconic pedestrian bridge over the River Liffey is one of Dublin's most photographed landmarks.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautifully lit at night; popular for strolls.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required to cross the bridge.

sites.name: The Little Museum of Dublin
sites.description: This museum offers a quirky and insightful view into the history of Dublin in the 20th century through a collection of everyday objects and stories.
sites.seasonal_notes: Guided tours provide a personal touch.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended due to limited space.

sites.name: O'Connell Street
sites.description: O'Connell Street is Dublin's main thoroughfare, known for its historical statues, the General Post Office, and a vibrant atmosphere.
sites.seasonal_notes: Busy year-round, especially during parades and public events.
sites.booking_tips: Explore on foot; no booking required.

sites.name: Croke Park Stadium
sites.description: Croke Park is the headquarters of the Gaelic Athletic Association and the third-largest stadium in Europe. It hosts major Gaelic games and concerts.
sites.seasonal_notes: Busy during major sporting events; quieter on non-match days.
sites.booking_tips: Tour tickets can be purchased online or on-site.

sites.name: Howth Head
sites.description: Howth Head is a picturesque peninsula offering stunning coastal views, hiking trails, and the charming village of Howth with its seafood restaurants.
sites.seasonal_notes: Ideal for hiking in spring and summer; windy in winter.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required; accessible by public transport.

sites.name: EPIC The Irish Emigration Museum
sites.description: EPIC is an interactive museum dedicated to the history of Irish emigration and the impact of the Irish diaspora worldwide.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round; interactive exhibits appeal to all ages.
sites.booking_tips: Tickets available online and at the entrance.

sites.name: Irish Museum of Modern Art (IMMA)
sites.description: Housed in the 17th-century Royal Hospital Kilmainham, IMMA is Ireland's leading national institution for the collection and presentation of modern and contemporary art.
sites.seasonal_notes: Special exhibitions may require entry fees.
sites.booking_tips: Check for special exhibits which may require separate tickets.

sites.name: The Iveagh Gardens
sites.description: Known as Dublin's 'Secret Garden', the Iveagh Gardens are a beautifully landscaped public park featuring fountains, woodlands, and a rosarium.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best visited in spring and summer when flowers are in bloom.
sites.booking_tips: No booking needed; a peaceful retreat in the city.
